meta.title: Philosophy
meta.audience: Beginners to intermediate learners interested in a comprehensive introduction to philosophy
meta.purpose: To provide a structured approach to learning philosophy, covering major areas and developing critical thinking skills

nodes.title: Introduction to Philosophy
nodes.objective: Gain a broad overview of philosophical inquiry and its main branches.

nodes.title: Read 'What Does It All Mean?' by Thomas Nagel
nodes.objective: Understand the fundamental questions of philosophy.
nodes.description: This short introduction covers major philosophical problems in an accessible way.

nodes.title: Reflect on Philosophical Questions
nodes.description:
What philosophical questions intrigued you the most?
How do these questions relate to your everyday life?
Which branch of philosophy are you most interested in exploring further?

nodes.title: Logic and Critical Thinking
nodes.objective: Develop skills in logical reasoning and argument analysis.

nodes.title: Study 'Introduction to Logic' by Irving M. Copi
nodes.objective: Learn the fundamentals of formal and informal logic.
nodes.description: Focus on Chapters 1-7 for a solid foundation in logical reasoning.

nodes.title: Practice Logical Reasoning
nodes.description: Complete exercises from the book and online resources like Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy's Logic section.

nodes.title: Ancient Philosophy
nodes.objective: Explore the foundations of Western philosophy.

nodes.title: Read 'A History of Western Philosophy' by Bertrand Russell
nodes.objective: Gain an overview of ancient Greek philosophy.
nodes.description: Focus on the sections about Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle.

nodes.title: Read Plato's 'Republic'
nodes.objective: Engage with a classic philosophical text.
nodes.description: Pay special attention to the Allegory of the Cave and discussions on justice.

nodes.title: Modern Philosophy
nodes.objective: Understand key developments in philosophy from the Renaissance to the 19th century.

nodes.title: Study 'Modern Philosophy: An Anthology of Primary Sources' edited by Roger Ariew and Eric Watkins
nodes.objective: Engage with primary texts from major modern philosophers.
nodes.description: Focus on works by Descartes, Hume, and Kant.

nodes.title: Write a Comparative Essay
nodes.description: Compare and contrast the epistemological views of Descartes and Hume.

nodes.title: Ethics and Moral Philosophy
nodes.objective: Explore major ethical theories and their applications.

nodes.title: Read 'The Elements of Moral Philosophy' by James Rachels
nodes.description: Pay special attention to utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue ethics.

nodes.title: Analyze Ethical Dilemmas
nodes.description: Apply different ethical frameworks to real-world scenarios.
